content.raw:
As outlined in my gazebo ticket linked above using the visual geometry for laser scanning is pretty much required as the robot would be able to "see through" objects otherwise and hence cheat. For example when walking through tall grass you probably wouldn't have collision geometry for it but rather simulate drag using some plugin - this would then allow the lidar to see the underlying terrain as it would not get blocked by the grass which would then largely simplify the problem of walking through tall grass. 

It also causes a lot of problems for perception when camera and lidar perceive different environments. Using the visual geometry for lasers' ray-tracing would allow you to use whatever simplified geometry you want without worrying about influence on the robot's perception system.

Speaking of lidar, the current gazebo lidar is still only running at ~34Hz instead of the full 40Hz.
